												One of the "Founding Fathers" Of PC FPS. Hell, maybe all FPS, it's so damn good. Facing Worlds is a reknown map to most gamers, and there's a reason for it.Let's get down to the basics of gameplay, what does it NEED to be a good game?Scroll to the bottom for final verdict!Graphics - This game is old. 1999 old. That's really ♥♥♥♥ing old. And yet... I still find some of these textures pleasing to the eye. The color scheme works well, and the environmental effects on some maps are pretty decent, for when this game was released, these graphics were revolutionary, just like Half-Life's. Some of the skins for characters even look pretty cool. The only issue I have with the graphics is that if you're trapped in a small box, like an elevator, it gets REALLY confusing. Combat - HAHAHAHAHA, Wow, if there's one thing you CAN'T insult about Unreal Tournament without being a complete ♥♥♥♥ing MORON, it's the COMBAT. I.... I've never played a game that can replicate how intense Unreal's combat is, aside from Counter-Strike. And it's a slightly different style, so even i'm not sure if CS can apply to compete with Unreal. Like I said, it is INTENSE. Even with easy bots, EVERYTHING moves at hyperspeed. Not just that, but things actually take a few seconds to kill. You have to take your shots wisely, and quickly. Most any weapon in the game will give your opponent the chance to turn around and fire back. Rocket Launcher, Sniper, and if you can manage it, Impact Hammers are the only exception. Maybe the flak cannon, but you have to get lucky with the spread. It isn't Call of Duty where you can knife a camper, or kill him with 3 bullets from an Assault Rifle....Speaking of camping, good luck with that. Standing still is just about the worst thing you can do in the game, not to mention there's barely any spots to do it. (Pillboxes on some of the maps excluded)Weapons - Unique as all hell! Lemme give you a run down of what weapons there are:-Impact Hammer: Your only melee. It sucks. Hold down your primary fire to charge it up and then slam it into someone to turn them into a meaty pile of flesh. Alternate Fire if they're at low health and you have nothing else.-Enforcer: Your pistol. Low in damage, and it also sucks. Primary fire does accurate shots, low fire-rate, alternate fire does highly inaccurate, high fire-rate shots. -GES biogun (or whatever it's called): A "Sortof" pistol, more like an SMG. It fires hazardous, glowing waste at your enemies, which procedes to melt them into a fine goo. Goo sticks to walls, and bursts after an amount of time, hurting any enemies nearby. Primary fire sprays it like a monkey throwing♥♥♥♥♥♥while on cocaine. Alternate fire charges a shot to make a giant, insta-kill ball of goo. "Insta-kill is over-powered, don't you think?" Nope. It is IMPOSSIBLE to hit somebody with the giant goo balls, the projectile is too slow, and the range is too short. You'd have to be hitting someone standing still, or get a lucky/skillfully aimed shot.-ASMD Shock Rifle: OH BOY A RAILGUN. Primary fire shoots a decently-powered bolt of blue energy, at instantanious speed. It is 100% accurate, no spread. Alternate fire shoots a ball of the same type of blue energy, at a slow speed. If you shoot the ball with another ball, or the primary fire bolt, it explodes into an electric explosion thingy that is sure to pastilize anyone nearby. In Unreal Tournament 3, the ball implodes, sucking any unlucky persons into a temporary black hole. THE MORE YOU KNOW!-Plasma Rifle: You can see the naming of this gun was just as unique as the previous ones /s. Primary fire shoots slow-moving tiny balls of green plasma ( that don't implode/explode D: ) which deal some.... pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good damage. Good for usage in tiny spaces like tunnels. Bad in outer areas. Like outside. Don't use it outside. Alternate fire shoots- ZOMG IT'S A♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ LAZOR BEAM!!!1! The laser beam has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ damage, but if you're accurate, you'll slice'n'dice your target in a second or two.-The Ripper: One of the nastiest ideas of a weapon i've heard of, The Ripper shoots giant mother-♥♥♥♥ing razor blades at your target. Some explode. We're getting emo on these ♥♥♥♥♥es. Primary fire shoots a highly volatile razor disc that ricochets like a bullet in a safe, and it doesn't stop until a while. WARNING: THERE IS A 75% CHANCE THESE BLADES WILL KILL YOU INSTEAD OF YOUR TARGET. DO NOT USE IN TIGHT QUARTERS. Alternate fire shoots an EXPLODING ♥♥♥♥ING RAZOR BLADE. WHO THOUGHT THIS ONE UP?!-Minigun: ....You know damn well what this gun does. Primary fire for semi-accurate, decent-speed minigun fire. Alternate for BBBBBBUUUUUULLLEEEEEETTTTT SSSSSSPPPPPAAAAAAAAMMMMM and extreme inaccuracy.-Flak Cannon: By far, my favorite gun. Essentially, it's a shotgun attached to a "Thumper" (grenade launcher). Primary fire shoots super-heated flak, which CAN bounce off of walls and kill you. Alternate fire shoots a grenade that explodes into flak.-Rocket Launcher: Primary fire for very slow rockets. Hold it down to prep up to 6 rockets, good for choke points. Alternate fire shoots ♥♥♥♥♥♥ pipe-bombs that hardly work. Hold down to prep up to 6 of them to launch.-Sniper Rifle: Primary shoots. Alternate scopes.-Redeemer: Primary fire destroys the universe. Alternate let's you find where you want to begin the destruction of the universe.They all feel good and fun, a generally enjoyable experience. The biggest complaint I have is with bots and Rocket Launchers, they aim a bit too good with those things in tight quarters.Maps: Some of the best map designs i've ever seen, I mean this game is doing better then CoD by a mile. There's hidden power-up rooms, treacherous hazards, risk-and-reward areas, seperate routes spread everywhere, and unique usage of the environment. Mother Nature(Property of Liandri Corp.) wants dat♥♥♥♥♥ boi.Story (for campaign): Ehhhh. This game didn't really have much. It gives you a starter intro, and some pretty good filler, as you can read up on your enemy's backstory as you prepare for battle. It even tells you their fighting styles. But the "story" is just some slapped on entertainment, the polish to the fancy sports car. Bosses/end battles: There is one, and ONLY one.Xan Kriegor.The whole game is you fighting your way to the top of the ranks of the Unreal Tournament to hopefully beat him and become the true champion. Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing christ, even on the easiest difficulty, this guy can be difficult. I'm still trying to beat him on one of the harder difficulties (I'm dreading the God-Like difficulty when I reach it). Essentially, Xan is the Shao Kahn (Mortal Kombat's final boss) of Unreal Tournament.Bonus Points: Terrific AI, and a ♥♥♥♥♥ON of difficulty settings. The options menu is also well-made, and the music is mindblowing.Final verdict: TENOUTTATEN. I'm serious, full 10/10. I can't give it less. I have yet to find a bug (aside from a bot getting stuck in a window a few times. Heh.) or issue with the game I do not like. It is one of the most well-programmed games ever made, the music is action-packed or sometimes relaxing, the maps, omfg the maps... This game is just awesome extract.HOWEVER,Despite the 10/10 rating, I do NOT suggest this game for all gamers. It is EXTREMELY fast-paced, you need fast reactions and fast hands (huehue) to get through it as a pro. Is the price right? Yes and no. Yes, it's worth it for the game, I URGE you to buy it. But no, as the game is pretty old by now, it should be lowered to atleast $7.50, though I believe $5.00 would be more appropriate.DO NOT LISTEN TO THE ♥♥♥♥WITS GIVING IT BAD RATINGS BECAUSE THEY CAN'T INSTALL IT. The game was made in 1999, and it's Window's fault if anything at all that they aren't compatible. Dual drivers have issues with the game's framerate, and more issues. The technical support page hasn't been updated in forever (Because this game was made in 1999, damnit).

												A classic and still my favorite Unreal title, the original Unreal Tournament is a marvel of gaming excellence and is a benchmark other deathmatch shooters should strive to meet.  My first encounter with this game was on the PS2 and this GotY Steam version is only better, so if you've ever played this game you should definitely pick up this improved version.  The gameplay is just as good as it always has been and hasn't added any unnecessary complexity with the GotY tag.  Its simplicity is what makes it so awesome, and this version is a prime example of that.  I could add that Mod support is built into the engine, the settings are excellent for such an old title, the gameplay is crisp, clean, and fast, the sound quality is superb...I could go on and on, but there shouldn't be any reason to.  If you like Multiplayer / Arena FPS you know what Unreal Tournament is and if you haven't played the original you're missing out on the game that defined the genre.  There are Quake fans, there are Unreal fans, there are Halo fans, and even Call of Duty fans, but all gamers can appreciate the history of the medium and the titles that laid the groundwork for the future, and Unreal Tournament is undeniably THE title that brought these types of games to the forefront of gaming culture. Pick it up for nostalgia's sake or even pick it up because it's still the best arena shooter created to date, Unreal Tournament is a game no FPS (or gaming) fan should lack and is just as fun today as when it hit the shelves all those years ago.A+, do not miss.

												I have to thank the DOOM 2016 open beta for introducing me to Unreal Tournament. I used to play DOOM 2 deathmatch over dialup when I was younger, and I was part of the Quake Alpha/Beta deathmatch trials back in the day. I loved online deathmatch, but went away from it for many years as FPS maps grew and gameplay slowed down. Playing DOOM 2016 deathmatch didn’t feel “right”, and the STEAM comments kept referring to Unreal as a much better online shooter experience. So I grabbed UT GOTY and the rest of the UT series. How right these commenters were….Unreal Tournament GOTY is one of the best games I have ever played. The graphics are amazing, the gameplay is action packed – so fast and adrenaline pumping. It is a pure Arena FPS, and in my opinion Unreal perfected the formula with UT GOTY. I’ve played the later games, which are fun in their own way – but this is just perfection. I loved the Mortal Kombat style voice over as the match went on…”Killing Spree….MULTI KILL” – and the tirade of smartass one liners from the bots, full of personality each one of them. The science fiction theme allows so much variety in levels, which are all full of colour and life…no brown and drab here. Musically, the tracks are all pumping electronica, that capture the essence of each level and the thrill of combat. The story, thin as it is, is all it needs to be – a couple of lines introducing the character or level, and the fact you are in an interstellar deathmatch tourney run by an evil corporation (cool!). The levels are awe inspiring, and I’d have to say the Facing World CTF map is up there with icons such as the Colosseum and Pyramids in its grandeur and online community reverence. No wonder it appears in all the sequels! Even if the online community dies off for this game (I can still get a match online today (2016) through the game which was released in 1999!) – I could always play with the bots, which are powered by the amazing Reaper technology which kept me hooked on Quake when I was younger. Thankfully I discovered this game late in life, otherwise I probably would have been hooked and not able to study or work or find a relationship. A masterpiece.

The review is written strictly from single-player perspective!Short version: 90%Unreal Tournament is one of the granddaddies of online team-based first-person shooters. It may have aged, but only in graphics, because the gameplay is still fast and exciting. And with its many game modes and high quality maps, it’s a game that you’ll never get bored of.Long version:First-person shooters weren’t always the on-rails, self-healing, cover-to-cover interactive movies they are today. This genre was a scene of highly competitive players who were constantly searching for the next game to test their limits. And in 1999 they got two of them, one being Unreal Tournament.The game featured a bundle of innovative weapons with two fire modes; memorable map design that is copied even today; game modes that finally showed something innovative beyond the same old death matches; and finally, bots which may feel a little dumb and predictable today, but back then they were topped only by Half-Life 1.UT may have been designed as a multiplayer game, but it is also enjoyable in single player. It has an actual campaign mode, where the “plot” may be simple as a doornail (you play in a futuristic gladiator tournament) and most participants only have a single-paragraph story, but it is still enough to build the foundation of a world you can immerse yourself in and make you care about your team. Because despite the popularity of free-for-all death matches, this game is all about team play.With the ever-increasing issues with the game engine (which was one of the best of its time) and the even more successful sequel, UT2004, UT ’99 faded into obscurity, but if you ever want some really old-school FPS action, you can always rely on it.

												I just revisited this game because I had such good memories of it. The variety of game types, the variety of weapons, the beauty of the maps, and the bot AI makes it the ultimate competitive FPS. It's all about the Tournament. And there are so many different kinds of tournament games to play, against real people or bots.What's also very nice is the ability to set up your own favourite kind of practice session, with bots of your choosing, on whatever map you want. So, for example, you can play capture the flag, you alone against a large army of stupid bots, or a single insanely good bot. Or you can have a bot team, and give them commands. Or you can just set up a bots-only competition, and just watch them go at it.Unreal Tournament has no need for a story. It's no-fuss interface allows the game-player to immediately launch themselves into the 'Unreal Tournament'- a futuristic fight-to-the-death, and as more scenarios are completed, four other game formats are introduced. There's 'capture the flag', in which you lead a team of fighters in an attempt to capture the opposing team's flag, all while defending your own. Following that, there's 'domination', a somewhat boring format that has your team controlling as many 'point scorers' as possible in order to amass your growing total to a winning score. The most exciting format is 'assault', whereby your team infiltrates either a submarine or a moving train, or whatever, in order to satisfy a number of mission objectives, all under a given time period. And don't forget that the game screams on today's machines -- smooth as silk, and very pretty.

												Not playing UT 99 is a crime to gamers everywhere. UT 99 is arguably the most competitive multiplayer FPS game right next to Counter Strike. This is not a friendly game, don't expect to come in and start whoopin'♥♥♥♥♥instantly...no, no...expect to come in and start getting YOUR♥♥♥♥♥whooped instantly. Fast paced, gory, frag fest action at its finest. UT 99 is a game that is simple, you grab a gun (My personal fav being the Flak Cannon) and go find some meat! The graphics of course may not be all that amazing, but graphics don't make a game, gameplay does and man does UT 99 offer that. With an arsenal of weaponry at your command and over a 100 maps, both by the dev, and the community, this is a game that I think will never get old, and the best part is after all these years, UT multiplayer is still going strong, just make sure you join a game with actual players and NOT bots. Trust me, you'll know if you are playing with bots or not. Single player is simple, you play in a tournament against bots, but personally, I skipped the campaign and went straight for the real deal multiplayer since I find fighting against bots...well boring. The soundtrack is foot-tappin awesomeness with fast techno tunes that go perfect with the sounds of rocket launchers and screams in the distance followed by the sound of body parts hitting the floor.There is a ton of gore in this game so be prepared. I think UT can stand up to any game today and still win, yes, even Battlefield 4. I like UT a lot more than Quake III for many reasons. It seems what Quake III was flawed at, UT 99 was improved in. Now don't get me wrong, I like UT 2004, but there is something about UT 99 that I like a lot more than 2004. I'm not sure but 99 is just wayyy more fun and awesome for me that 2004 ever was. What else is there to say, it's fast, it's action-packed, it's gruesome, it's frantic, it's insane, it's intense, it's UT 99! And no need to worry about specs, any modern CPU can run this game perfectly smooth with no lag at all, believe me, I have a 1.0 GHZ processor laptop with AMD c-50 dual core. This is essential if you call yourself a PC gamer, and for the price of a book, you'd be silly NOT to buy this game! Don't let the difficulty of this game turn you off at first, UT is a game that is fun to play, but hard to master, it just takes time and patience to finally start getting into the swing of things and starting to get kills. So play UT 99 today! I'm sure you'll enjoy seeing your avatar die in an explosion of blood and limbs...:3

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												Unreal Tournament is another absolute classic and was a worthy contender against other online First Person Shooters such as Quake 3 Arena. The game was a spinoff title to Unreal. However unlike Unreal (which focused on single player), the game was instead an arena shooter with online multiplayer in mind. Despite this the game does have a single player campaign. The story for this game is as follows, 100 years has passed since the events within Unreal, a mining corporation known as Liandri is hosting a no-holds-barred fighting tournament. You have entered the Tournament to become the next champion, by competing in 4 different leagues which have their own game modes and unlock the fifth league in order to beat the previous tournament champion Xan. There really isn’t much to the story and whilst there is more information within the single player campaign explaining the lore, character motivations and certain events within the Unreal Universe, it really doesn’t add that much to the overall story.  The graphics weren’t a huge improvement over Unreal, the reason for this was to increase performance when playing the game and maintain a high framerate with its fast pace gameplay. Despite this the game was still good looking for its time and the locations, level design, ascetics and environments in some maps is absolutely jaw dropping. A lot of the maps where set in different locations such as inside a spaceship, on an asteroid floating in space, inside an old medieval castle etc. It made each map feel more different and unique from each other. The soundtrack is also to the same quality as Unreal and is extremely good with some standouts like Foregone Destruction and Mechanism Eight.  In terms of gameplay you are given 6 different game modes, deathmatch which is a free for all, team deathmatch where two teams battle each other and the team with the most kills usually wins, capture the flag where two teams have to get the enemies team flag and bring it back to their own flag without the enemy taking theirs, domination where two teams have to take and keep control of key locations across the map, last man standing which is similar to deathmatch only players are given a full arsenal of weapons and have to stay alive as long as possible and assault which was a brand new game mode for its time. This is where players where broken up into two teams.(offensive and defensive)The offensive team have to complete key objectives in order to advance and win, the defenders have to prevent the other team from completing these objectives for as long as possible or until the timer ran out, both teams alternate and whichever team defends the longest wins. The weapons in this game vary from familiar favourites such as the Flak Cannon and the Minigun and some new weapons like the Pulse Gun which replaces the Stinger. Each returning weapon has been given a minor tweak, such as having a faster rate of fire. The standout weapon among all of these is the newly added Redeemer a one use weapon which fires a rocket with a powerful area of effect annihilating anything within its radius. The bot’s in this game are extremely good and highly intelligent offering up a challenge when the player needs it. Overall Unreal Tournament is a fantastic game and is still fun to play today. The bots are a good enough challenge to play with and even though it isn’t played as much online today you can still find a game with a few people to fill in the server or if you’re setting up a LAN event any time soon then this game should be on your list.

												I am usually quite ambiguous when it comes to evaluating games; even the most critically acclaimed game may fall down into the mire from the right perspective (looking at you FO4). However there are a select few games which I would consider "Must Plays". Games so important and timeless that - provided you have any interest in the genre what-so-ever - you have to own. Oblivion would be such a game for the open-world genre, Dawn of War for the RTS genre. Why? Neither game is perfect by any means, but they are landmarks, marking turning points and signifying a leap forwards.The FPS genre could have a number of games put forwards for this presitgious honour, but for reasons which shall soon become apparent, the only real contender is Unreal Tournament.UT99 as it shall be referred to from here on, marked the modernisation of a format which had been in the making for several years. Quake 3 Arena was a popular alternative but play Quake 3 now, and while it is still thoroughly enjoyable, it feels old. It still has the terrible animations, the clinically un-atmospheric environments, the soapy aftertaste of a game lacking in passion and excitement.UT99 put all of this right. The levels were beautifully designed and characterful, with each and every square inch dripping with details and offering a plethora of combat options. Every weapon had its own personality, there was no progression or advancement from one to the next; just a change in options. Even the characters each had sparks of life in their eyes. But what really set it apart from the rest of the pack was the music. Without the music, UT99 would have been a great game. But the soundtrack elevated it up to the prestigious podium of mastercrafted perfection.UT99 set new standard for combat, level design, graphic capability, combat scale and bot intelligence. However it's use of  musical scores changed the way games would be designed forever. UT99's stablemates in its year of release almost uniformly did away with soundtracks, save for the occasional musical score. In the year following its release, soundtracks became more common, especially noticable in games like No One Lives Forever and Hitman. Go forwards just one more year, and games such as Halo and Serious Sam join the fray. Both very different games, but what do they have in common? Iconic soundtracks.UT99 is a fundementally vital game for the advancement of the FPS and the arena shooter, and it deserves its place in the halls of fame (and your library) for that alone. However the next time you notice the musical atmosphere in a game, remember that you have this game to thank.

												Short: A must-have classics of videogaming. Still totally worth playing today. Why to buy it: Historical masterpiece. Perfect for relaxation. It helps to find peace and emptiness after a hard day at work. More efficient than meditation, sauna, or sport. Long version:Unreal Tournament has something magical. It has been years since its original release, and still, it's amazingly good and definitely worth playing. For those who do not know this ultimate legend of FPS, let me introduce it in a few lines :Most FPS have tried to find a neat story to keep the player into the game. Then someone came and said: "Hey, guys, why do we care with a story? Don't we play only to shoot and have fun, after all?" And so came Unreal Tournament. The idea is that you are a gladiator in a futuristic universe, with some interesting background with appreciable ties with the Unreal universe. So you are in an arena with guns spread everywhere, and if you are killed, you just instantly respawn and continue the fight. It means there is no break, no searching for the way forward, for stupid opening buttons. You just fight and fight and fight endlessly, until you win the match. The experience was, and still remains, an extremely intense one. Videogame here is at its greater height, even if it's shear violence and barbarousness. Now, is it still worth today? The graphics have aged, for sure, but the level design was so good, that it doesn't matter a lot. They did not try to build magnificent open spaces areas in a luxurious nature: Most arenas are confined basements, and this is the kind of decor which cannot be much prettier today than it was seventeen years ago. Gameplay is still pretty much perfect. Weapons are sufficiently hidden so that you have to find out where they are while trying not being killed by those who already have them, and there is a good diversity of them. Everything was well-balanced then, and it has remained so up to now, as equilibrium never ages. What feels like the twentieth century, however, is the AI if you play solo, especially in Assault mode, where your team keeps following you, backing you up in the most useless manner. That means that if you are almost at the objective, and you die, you return to the starting point, and your team, instead of finishing what you were up to, just left the enemy base to greet you in pack at your respawn place. To end this review, I will tell you some personal story I have with this game. In my youth years I was often bullied by a big tough guy; but one day we spoke and, I don't know really how, we ended up by him lending me his Unreal Tournament game. I enjoyed it a lot, and now that we had a common enthralling to share, we became good lads and he never bullied me again. Peace among people can be achieved through cathartic  videogaming, it would seem.

												Full Disclosure: I am a long-time consumer of the Unreal series, and a nearly life-long fan of both the Unreal series and Epic Games, the developer of said series. As such, I may be VERY biased, and my word might not be completely reliable, though I will try as usual to be as fair as possible.Unreal Tournament is an Arena FPS whom is THE grandfather of the entire genre, of games which are entirely based upon combat in planned stages designed solely for combat, not story. It has fallen into obscurity since Unreal Tournament 2004's release, so allow me to try and show you how this game became such a staple of gaming.These days, you've got games that run natively at 60fps, support resolutions for 4K monitors and ultra-wide monitors, and you've got games now which are nearly realistic for appearance. Unreal Tournament, came a bit late, but used it's engine well, Unreal Engine 1, which originated in the first Unreal game, which is an Engine that, even in the 90s, was the cutting edge of graphic fidelity and quality. It stands up even now, despite using polygons, lacking facial animations, but each weapon, and each character looks great even still. Levels still look gorgeous and cool, and almost falling into space still makes me very antsy even after 12 years later.The game has only three modes. The Singleplayer Campaign, Multiplayer, and an offline skirmish-style mode titled Instant Action. The Campaign is of you, a new combatant in the newest deathsport known as the Unreal Tournament, where convicts have been turned into gladiators whom kill one another and win with the goal of becoming The Tournament Champion, effectively attaining a sort of celebrity-status. Multiplayer is smooth and reliable. There are no problems with the game itself that I've found, even with this re-release. Modes for it, are identical to Instant Action, only some maps function with people, as you don't need AI pathing with human players.Instant Action's modes are Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Last Man Standing, Capture The Flag, Assault and Domination.The only ones which aren't obvious and in other games, are Domination and Assault, so I will describe them.Assault, is by far my favorite mode in virtually any game and it is a team-based mode with two teams. One team attacks a base, completing preset objectives and eventually aiming to complete them all, while the other team's objective is to stop the attacking team from completing objectives by any means.Once the attacking team completes their objectives, they win the match, should they do all objectives and both teams switch sides, the defensive team becomes the new attacker, and vice-versa. At this point, the newly attacking team must match the completion time of the other team, or they will suffer a loss of the match. Though the sides switch even if the first attackers don't succeed, allowing both teams to attack and defend each match.Domination, on the other hand, is a sort of variant of traditional King of The Hill gamemodes. Only there are multiple Hills, or Points, which either team (up to 4 teams, unlike other modes, save for TDM) must hold to win the match. Holding a point wil generate one score point for the team every 3 seconds or so, and holding more points will generate more.It also has something no non-Unreal title has ever really adopted whole-heartedly; Mutators. Think of a mod, imagine how annoying it is that you can't just tick it on or off, or combine it with others witohut conflict for the most part. Mutators allow you to change parts of the game, like Low Gravity, and entirely different set of weapons, or powerful relics that change the game's strategies, or even classics like Volatile Ammo (ammo that is shot will discharge, resulting in hilarity from shooting ammo than the enemy) and Fatboy (Where your character model gets more "fat" or just wider, with obvious texture stretching, based on how well you're doing. Whoever wins, usually ends up being the fattest, while the one who did the worst, ends up like a skinny stick figure).Due to the game being made in the 90s, the options menu isn't TOO varied, but it sort of gets hte job done.It's got Video Driver settings, Resolution, graphics quality, texture quality (32 bit and 16 bit), A minimum FPS setting for video settings. It has the usual for audio, which technically hasn't changed for many games in years. You can alter the in-game auto-swap priority for different weapons, I personally have dual enforcers at the top above the sniper rifle. Input options are fairly varied with two different forms of sensitivity, and different mouse-based look options.The game is difficult... if you want it to be. It has quite literally 12 different difficulties, from Novice to Godlike, there's almost no way anybody is too awful to play any difficulty of this game. With Novice, AI are painfully stupid, maybe even intentionally avoiding powerups in at least early singleplayer levels, whereas in Godlike, the AI become Kung-Fu gun masters, constantly know where you are and instinctually know when items respawn and always try to hog powerups aswell as having almost perfect aim and reaction, even mimicking players by spastically jumping around.This game's soundtrack holds up today. In Unreal Tournament 3, most of hte songs are simply remixes of classic songs from this game, there's almost no single song that hasn't made it, and the music in this game are great for listenning when working out, writing, or even playing other games with.The announcer is also very well voiced. It's dominantly used for custom content quite often, mostly in Gmod, though it's confused for the Announcer in Quake 3 Arena... which is actually more of a knock-off with 90% less recorded dialogue and announcements.The game has barely any Story. IN the campaign, you are a newly brought-in convict in charge of your own team. Your goal? To climb the ladder of this tournament deathsport (which is canon as a sort of reality show to the human race) and to become the Tournament Champion by defeating it's first champion, Xan Kreigor... who is really hard to kill in-game. That's it though. You gain trophies though, and they still look cool!The game comes with a decent amount of content, but given how some still play multiplayer, and that if you look in the right places, you can find over 10 GBs worth of custome content. Given how I once had only 2 gbs of content on my copy of the game in the past, that was over 500 maps, 7 game modes, 4 mods, and many mutators.Some of these maps have neutral AI players which are super-powerful and are remixed versions of other official maps, using a different theme, or maps of such quality, you'd thinkSome of these custom gamemodes is the wonderful Monster Hunt, like Assault, but the defending team is always the monsters, and the players are always attacking to get to the end before losing all their lives, or the chaotic 4-Team Capture The Flag. My second favorite is Jailbreak, bbasically Team Deathmatch meets Capture The Flag. Two teams aiming to kill one another and jail them, then watch them get executed, sometimes able to have prisoners of either team pit against one another in a 1v1 where the winner goes free, and it's possible to release your team by going into enemy territory.This game is simply one of my favorites. It's always been one of my favorite as I can't remember a time it wasn't installed on my computer. Even just to play the Campaign, I've never forgotten this game, and I always have had a copy of it since I first played it when I was 10. If you like FPS games, or the idea of a gladiatorial arena-style game tickles your fancy, then pick this game up. There's more custom content than what I suggested like voice packs, models, even Total Conversions and far more.I recommend this due to it simply being one of the best Arena FPS' to ever appear on the market. I don't think you'll regret your purchase.

 Curator-esque Review Only your skills and map knowledge will save you here.  The AI of the bots is brutal, the soundtrack thumping, and the arenas are classics that hold up despite their age.  Online multiplayer is dead and gone so realize you are buying this game for its singleplayer experience. Unreal Tournament: Game of the Year Edition Review  Story In 2291, the New Earth Government (NEG) legalizes "consentual murder" as a form of entertainment.  Due to an increase in reports of violence among deep space miners, the NEG sees the organization of gladitorial tournaments as a means of redirecting unrest among the working class for profit.  The largest mining corporation, Liandri Mining Corp. (LMC) begins providing arenas for the Tournament as well as broadcasting the event throughout the known galaxy.  LMC's profits soar as athletes, condemned criminals, mercenaries, soldiers, and regular citizens travel across the universe to compete.The game takes place fifty years after the NEG's unprecedented decision.  As one character from a diverse roster of participants, the player competes in the Tournament's various events for unique reasons.  The ultimate goal?  Depose Xan Kriegor, the undefeated Tournament champion, and claim universal renown. Gameplay A first person shooter (FPS) in the truest sense, Unreal Tournament 1999 (UT99) sees players compete against AI and/or human opponents in a variety of game modes.  Deathmatch and Team Deathmatch have players racing to be the first to get a set amount of kills alone or as a team respectively.  Domination sees two teams fighting over control points, with every point controlled adding to the respective team's total; the first team to accrue a set amount of points wins.  Capture the Flag has the teams capture the enemy flag for points while defending their own at the same time.  Finally, Assault has one team in an offensive role while the opposite team plays a defensive role.  Maps that assualt take place on require the attacking team to complete a series of objectives while the defending team prevents them from doing so.  At the end of a round of Assault, the teams switch roles and the now attackers must either complete more of the assualt than the former attackers or complete the map in less than the time it took the former attackers to complete.  The singleplayer portion of the game involves playing through a certain amount of a particular gametype until the next Tournament rung is unlocked.  Each time you start a new rung, there is an optional tutorial level explaining how to play that particular gamemode.  Singleplayer is essentially matches against AI opponents who can be set to various difficulty levels.  The bot AI is one of the great things about UT99 because bots behave in a challenging, almost adaptive manner. Each game mode features maps designed solely for that gamemode with the exception of a few overlapping arenas.  Assault maps are the most linear whereas Deathmatch maps are more open. Some arenas are symmetric while others asymetric and complicated.  A few arenas even feature a special condition, such as "Morpheus" which takes place atop a stratospheric skyscraper and features low gravity for huge jumps.  Filling these outlandish arenas is a plethora of futuristic and conventional weaponry.  Take the plasma rifle for example: primary fire is a straight beam, secondary fire is a slower moving orb, but if you shoot the secondary projectile with the primary fire, it detonates causing a small explosion.  Most weapons feature an alternate fire mode and can only be reloaded by picking up ammo scattered around the arena.  Steady aim is important as most weapons chew through ammo fairly quick.  Health vials and various armor pieces can be picked up to increase your longevity although respawning is instantaneous, giving gameplay a brisk and hectic pace.  There are also items scattered around arenas to pick up like the anti-grav boots for huge jumps and scuba gear for underwater breathing.  Finally, modifiers can be found in somewhat hard to reach places that can boost your damage with weapons, health, or even make you invisble.  Knowing arena layouts, the limitations of each weapon, and where modifiers spawn is essential to victory.Unfortunately due to the age of the game, you should expect to only play UT99 in singleplayer as there are not many games to be found online.  Although sold as UT99: Game of the Year Edition, this version on Steam does not in fact include the game of the year content.  Ambitious players can attempt to track the extra content down however I have read that the missing content does not amount to much anyway compared to the base game.  Design Every match in UT99 begins in free roam mode.  This allows you to fly around the map and learn where all the weapon/item spawns are, where the enemy base is, and where conflicts are likely to occur.  Free roam is also nice in that you can see just how detailed certain arenas can be.  Built on the same engine as Unreal (Epic Game's 1998 title), UT99 is definitely an old looking game in terms of chracter and environmental models.  However, every arena feels unique in its tone and atmosphere.  From the lighting to the architectural theme of each map, the level design feels thoughtful as well as considerate of the type of game UT99 is.  Adding to the frantic nature of the game is a nice electronic soundtrack featuring lots of drum and bass.  Who can forget the music of "Facing Worlds"?  Characters are voiced appropriately over-the-top and the weapons sound sharp and distinct.  The game features a thorough list of options so players can tailor and mod the game as they see fit.    Final Thoughts Long before I was a PC gamer, I played the Infogrames Playstation 2 port of UT99.  It featured updated textures and additional maps not found here on the Steam version, but aiming was clunky with an analog stick.  I purchased the steam version largely out of nostalgia and a desire to play the game as it was meant to be played.  In these respects, UT99 did not disappoint me even though I was retreading ground.  Unfortunately due to the age of the game, you should expect to only play UT99 in singleplayer or with friends as there are not many games to be found online.  From the soundtrack to fast-paced tone of the game, UT99 and its 2004 successor are  the  arena shooters in my mind.

												Still as much fun today as it was back when it was first released. Truly a game that stands the tests of time.A frantic, fast-paced FPS that's filled with action. High game speed, little to no cover, and very few places to hide. The weapons are quite unique and with each weapon having 2 firing modes, the different playstyles one can adopt are plenty. A game that is still a lot of fun to play competitive against your friends in.The amount of game modes offered are decent enough, considering its age. Most are pretty standard game modes that one usually expects from games with competitive multiplayer, but it does offer some that stand out such as Assault. It also has a fair amount of maps, most of which are very memorable and iconic. There are also a lot of fan made custom maps that are easy to put into the game.

												Well, here I am at 6 AM writing this review on my first game ever played.This game series was sort of a joyride for the first few Unreal Engines - all the way up to UT2K4.I'll always miss this game and the fun I had with it. So many servers are still active to this day despite coming out in 1999, being the main competitor of Quake at the time. This game stuck in my head for so many years and I still listen to its amazing soundtracks. I first got it back sometime when I was really young, and despite not knowing what I was doing then, I played the crap out of this game nonetheless. If you get the game (which I heavily recommend you do on all levels) I'd try out Monsterhunt as a gamemode eventually but don't forget to try offline with bots. With all the mutators and modifications you can make to your private games it is endless joy. There is also an offline vs bots Tournament (hence the name) where you can climb the ladders of different gamemodes to fight the final boss who I will not spoil for you, but is also my favorite UT character.Enjoy!
